🛑 Ensure Data Backup 💾 Disclaimer is given Before Initiating:
⚠️ RESET ⚠️ OSRI ⚠️ SYSTEM RESTORE

🚨 UNSUPPORTED PRODUCTS - ROUTE TO DSO TEAM: 5X-Workstations • TB-Displays • 2C-ThinClient • I1-ThinClientL10 • US-Retail • UT-Digital Signage • UV-Mobile Thin Clients • 6V/GU-Sprout • GB-ElitePOS • GV-3DCapture • I0-MiniWork • BQ-VRHeadsets • EZ-Tablets • MO-HPSlice • IQ-RetailDesktop 🚨

1. Power Drain

Please try a Power Drain. This will discharge any static electricity that may be trapped inside the system, which can cause the unit to not function properly.

Could you please follow the steps below:

  • • Shut down the unit.
  • • Disconnect all external devices (including the power adapter).
  • • Press and hold the Power button for approximately 25–30 seconds.
  • • After 2–3 minutes, reconnect the AC adapter and try to turn the computer back on.

Please keep us posted on the outcome.

<

2. BIOS Recovery

Please try the BIOS recovery steps below: This attempts to restore the BIOS from a hidden partition on the hard drive.

  • • Turn off the computer and make sure the AC adapter is plugged in.
  • • Press and hold the Windows + b keys at the same time.
  • • While still holding those keys, press the power button for 2-3 seconds and then release it.
  • • Continue holding the Windows + b keys until the HP BIOS Update screen appears or you hear a series of beeps.
  • • If the Windows + b keys don't work, please try the exact same process using the Windows + v keys instead.

Here is the video for your reference: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qpiGUojtr3E

3. CMOS Reset

**Reference Document:** https://support.hp.com/my-en/document/ish_11469889-11469938-16

Please follow the steps below for your device type:

Consumer All‐in‐Ones & Desktops

  • • Connect the AC adapter.
  • • Press and hold the power button for more than 20 seconds.
  • • Release the button; “Default BIOS settings have been loaded” is displayed.
  • • The computer restarts; you can now access BIOS or UEFI Diagnostics.

Consumer Notebooks

  • • Plug in the AC adapter.
  • • Turn off and wait at least 5 seconds.
  • • Press and hold Windows + V.
  • • While holding those, press and hold the power button for 2–3 seconds.
  • • Release the power button (keep holding Windows + V) until the CMOS Reset screen appears or you hear beeps.
  • • The unit restarts with default BIOS settings.
  • • Note: An “invalid checksum” message is normal; the reboot clears it.

G11 & Later Business Notebooks/Workstations

  • • Hold the power button for at least 12 seconds to turn off.
  • • Press and hold Windows + V on the built-in keyboard, then press the power button.
  • • After reset, a confirmation message appears; press Enter to restart.
  • • Note: “Invalid checksum” is normal; the reboot clears it.

G7–G10 & Certain G11 Business Notebooks

  • • Turn off the computer.
  • • Press and hold the power button for 25 seconds, then release and power on.
  • • After reset, a confirmation message appears; press Enter to restart.
  • • Note: “Invalid checksum” is normal; the reboot clears it.
  • • Press enter to restart the computer.

Please try the above steps and keep us posted on the outcome.

4. Find Serial Number

Your Serial Number and Product Number are essential for getting the correct support. Here’s a quick guide to help you find them.

For Computers (Laptops & Desktops)

Easiest Software Methods:

  • • Please Press FN KEY + ESC KEY together and look for the serial number and product number in the popped up window and help me with the same.
  • • Using HP Support Assistant: Open the app. Your Serial Number is on the main "My Dashboard" screen.
  • • Using Windows Command Prompt: Open Command Prompt (search for "cmd"), type wmic bios get serialnumber and press Enter.

Physical Locations:

  • • Look for a printed label on the bottom of your laptop, on the side/back of a desktop case, or on the back of an All-in-One.
  • • The serial number is also on a sticker on the original box.

For Chromebooks

  • • From Sign-in Screen: Before logging in, press the Alt + v keys at the same time to see the serial number.
  • • On the Label: Check for a sticker on the bottom of the Chromebook.

For Monitors & Accessories

  • • Look for a label on the back or underside of the device.
  • • For smaller items, check for laser-etched text on the surface.
  • • You can also find it on the original packaging or your purchase receipt.

For more detailed instructions, see these resources:

Reference Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_N8BfdCvMRg
HP Support Article: https://support.hp.com/in-en/document/ish_2039298-1862169-16

5. Boot into BIOS

Please follow these steps to boot into BIOS:

  • • Unit should be in shutdown state.
  • • Press the power button and press the 'esc' key repeatedly.
  • • Once you are in the Boot menu, press F10 to enter BIOS.

6.1 UEFI Test - System Board

The system board (motherboard) is the main circuit board that connects all components. This test verifies that the motherboard's circuits, power distribution, and component connections are functioning properly.

Request you to please follow the below steps for System Board:

  • Step 1: Unit should be in shutdown state.
  • Step 2: Press the power button and press the 'esc' key repeatedly.
  • Step 3: Once you are in the Boot menu, Press F2 to enter UEFI.
  • Step 4: Select COMPONENT TEST and select system board.
  • Step 5: Select and quick test.

Once completed, request you to please share an image of the test result in the chat.

6.2 UEFI Test - Wireless Module

The wireless module enables Wi-Fi and Bluetooth connectivity. This test checks if the wireless hardware can properly transmit and receive signals, ensuring you can connect to networks and wireless devices.

Request you to please follow the below steps for Wireless Module:

  • Step 1: Unit should be in shutdown state.
  • Step 2: Press the power button and press the 'esc' key repeatedly.
  • Step 3: Once you are in the Boot menu, Press F2 to enter UEFI.
  • Step 4: Select COMPONENT TEST and select wireless module.
  • Step 5: Select and quick test.

Once completed, request you to please share an image of the test result in the chat.

6.3 UEFI Test - Battery

The battery provides portable power to your laptop. This test evaluates the battery's health, capacity, and charging ability to ensure it can hold charge and provide expected runtime.

Request you to please follow the below steps for Battery:

  • Step 1: Unit should be in shutdown state.
  • Step 2: Press the power button and press the 'esc' key repeatedly.
  • Step 3: Once you are in the Boot menu, Press F2 to enter UEFI.
  • Step 4: Select COMPONENT TEST and select power and choose battery.
  • Step 5: Select and quick test.

Once completed, request you to please share an image of the test result in the chat.

6.4 UEFI Test - Adapter

The power adapter charges your battery and powers the laptop. This test verifies that the adapter can provide stable power at the correct voltage and that the charging circuit is working properly.

Request you to please follow the below steps for Adapter:

  • Step 1: Unit should be in shutdown state.
  • Step 2: Press the power button and press the 'esc' key repeatedly.
  • Step 3: Once you are in the Boot menu, Press F2 to enter UEFI.
  • Step 4: Select COMPONENT TEST and select power and choose Adapter.
  • Step 5: Select and quick test.

Once completed, request you to please share an image of the test result in the chat.

6.5 UEFI Test - Speaker

Speakers provide audio output for your laptop. This test checks if the audio drivers, sound card, and speakers can produce clear sound at different frequencies and volumes.

Request you to please follow the below steps for Speaker:

  • Step 1: Unit should be in shutdown state.
  • Step 2: Press the power button and press the 'esc' key repeatedly.
  • Step 3: Once you are in the Boot menu, Press F2 to enter UEFI.
  • Step 4: Select COMPONENT TEST and select Audio.
  • Step 5: Select and quick test.

Once completed, request you to please share an image of the test result in the chat.

6.6 UEFI Test - Microphone

The microphone captures audio input for calls, recordings, and voice commands. This test verifies that the microphone can properly detect and record sound with appropriate sensitivity levels.

Request you to please follow the below steps for Microphone:

  • Step 1: Unit should be in shutdown state.
  • Step 2: Press the power button and press the 'esc' key repeatedly.
  • Step 3: Once you are in the Boot menu, Press F2 to enter UEFI.
  • Step 4: Select COMPONENT TEST and select microphone.
  • Step 5: Select and quick test.

Once completed, request you to please share an image of the test result in the chat.

6.7 UEFI Test - Touchpad

The touchpad serves as your laptop's built-in mouse. This test checks if the touchpad can accurately detect finger movements, clicks, gestures, and multi-touch functions.

Request you to please follow the below steps for Touchpad:

  • Step 1: Unit should be in shutdown state.
  • Step 2: Press the power button and press the 'esc' key repeatedly.
  • Step 3: Once you are in the Boot menu, Press F2 to enter UEFI.
  • Step 4: Select COMPONENT TEST and select touchpad.
  • Step 5: Select and quick test.

Once completed, request you to please share an image of the test result in the chat.

6.8 UEFI Test - Keyboard

The keyboard is essential for typing and system control. This test verifies that all keys register properly, function keys work, and special key combinations respond correctly.

Request you to please follow the below steps for Keyboard:

  • Step 1: Unit should be in shutdown state.
  • Step 2: Press the power button and press the 'esc' key repeatedly.
  • Step 3: Once you are in the Boot menu, Press F2 to enter UEFI.
  • Step 4: Select COMPONENT TEST and select keyboard.
  • Step 5: Select and quick test.

Once completed, request you to please share an image of the test result in the chat.

6.9 UEFI Test - SSD/HDD

Your storage drive (SSD/HDD) stores your operating system, programs, and files. This test checks for bad sectors, read/write speeds, and overall drive health to prevent data loss.

Request you to please follow the below steps for SSD/HDD:

  • Step 1: Unit should be in shutdown state.
  • Step 2: Press the power button and press the 'esc' key repeatedly.
  • Step 3: Once you are in the Boot menu, Press F2 to enter UEFI.
  • Step 4: Select COMPONENT TEST and select storage and select SSD.
  • Step 5: Select and quick test.

Once completed, request you to please share an image of the test result in the chat.

10 UEFI Test - Port

USB and other ports allow you to connect external devices like mice, keyboards, and storage drives. This test ensures all ports can properly detect and communicate with connected devices.

Request you to please follow the below steps for Port:

  • Step 1: Unit should be in shutdown state.
  • Step 2: Press the power button and press the 'esc' key repeatedly.
  • Step 3: Once you are in the Boot menu, Press F2 to enter UEFI.
  • Step 4: Select COMPONENT TEST and select PORT.
  • Step 5: Select and quick test.

Once completed, request you to please share an image of the test result in the chat.

6.11 UEFI Test - Webcam

The webcam captures video for video calls and photos. This test verifies that the camera sensor, lens, and image processing work correctly to produce clear video output.

Request you to please follow the below steps for Webcam:

  • Step 1: Unit should be in shutdown state.
  • Step 2: Press the power button and press the 'esc' key repeatedly.
  • Step 3: Once you are in the Boot menu, Press F2 to enter UEFI.
  • Step 4: Select COMPONENT TEST and select webcam.
  • Step 5: Select and quick test.

Once completed, request you to please share an image of the test result in the chat.

6.12 UEFI Test - Fan

The cooling fan prevents your laptop from overheating by circulating air. This test checks if the fan spins at proper speeds and responds correctly to temperature changes to protect your components.

Request you to please follow the below steps for Fan:

  • Step 1: Unit should be in shutdown state.
  • Step 2: Press the power button and press the 'esc' key repeatedly.
  • Step 3: Once you are in the Boot menu, Press F2 to enter UEFI.
  • Step 4: Select COMPONENT TEST and select Fan.
  • Step 5: Select and quick test.

Once completed, request you to please share an image of the test result in the chat.

6.13 UEFI Test - Fingerprint

The fingerprint sensor provides biometric security for quick and secure login. This test verifies that the sensor can accurately read and recognize fingerprint patterns for authentication.

Request you to please follow the below steps for FingerPrint Module:

  • Step 1: Unit should be in shutdown state.
  • Step 2: Press the power button and press the 'esc' key repeatedly.
  • Step 3: Once you are in the Boot menu, Press F2 to enter UEFI.
  • Step 4: Select COMPONENT TEST and select Fingerprint.
  • Step 5: Select and quick test.

Once completed, request you to please share an image of the test result in the chat.

6.14 UEFI Test - Processor

The processor (CPU) is the brain of your computer that executes all programs. This test verifies that all processor cores function correctly and can handle computational tasks at proper speeds.

Request you to please follow the below steps for Processor:

  • Step 1: Unit should be in shutdown state.
  • Step 2: Press the power button and press the 'esc' key repeatedly.
  • Step 3: Once you are in the Boot menu, Press F2 to enter UEFI.
  • Step 4: Select COMPONENT TEST and select processor.
  • Step 5: Select and quick test.

Once completed, request you to please share an image of the test result in the chat.

6.15 UEFI Test - Memory

RAM (system memory) temporarily stores data that your processor needs quick access to. This test checks for memory errors, proper data storage/retrieval, and ensures stable system performance.

Request you to please follow the below steps for Memory:

  • Step 1: Unit should be in shutdown state.
  • Step 2: Press the power button and press the 'esc' key repeatedly.
  • Step 3: Once you are in the Boot menu, Press F2 to enter UEFI.
  • Step 4: Select COMPONENT TEST and select memory.
  • Step 5: Select and quick test.

Once completed, request you to please share an image of the test result in the chat.

6.16 UEFI Test - Video Memory

Video memory (VRAM) stores graphics data for your display. This test ensures the graphics card's memory can properly handle video rendering, gaming, and visual effects without artifacts or crashes.

Request you to please follow the below steps for Video Memory:

  • Step 1: Unit should be in shutdown state.
  • Step 2: Press the power button and press the 'esc' key repeatedly.
  • Step 3: Once you are in the Boot menu, Press F2 to enter UEFI.
  • Step 4: Select COMPONENT TEST and select video and choose video memory.
  • Step 5: Select and quick test.

Once completed, request you to please share an image of the test result in the chat.

6.17 UEFI Test - Mouse

An external mouse provides precise cursor control for detailed work. This test verifies that connected mice can track movement accurately and all buttons function properly.

Request you to please follow the below steps for Mouse:

  • Step 1: Unit should be in shutdown state.
  • Step 2: Press the power button and press the 'esc' key repeatedly.
  • Step 3: Once you are in the Boot menu, Press F2 to enter UEFI.
  • Step 4: Select COMPONENT TEST and select Input Device and choose Mouse.
  • Step 5: Select and quick test.

Once completed, request you to please share an image of the test result in the chat.

6.18 UEFI Test - Touch Screen

Touchscreen functionality allows direct interaction with your display. This test checks if the touch sensors can accurately detect finger positions, gestures, and multi-touch inputs across the entire screen.

Request you to please follow the below steps for Touch Screen:

  • Step 1: Unit should be in shutdown state.
  • Step 2: Press the power button and press the 'esc' key repeatedly.
  • Step 3: Once you are in the Boot menu, Press F2 to enter UEFI.
  • Step 4: Select COMPONENT TEST and select Input Device and choose Touch Screen.
  • Step 5: Select and quick test.

Once completed, request you to please share an image of the test result in the chat.

7.1 Device Manager - Uninstall Battery Drivers

Battery drivers manage power consumption and charging behavior. Uninstalling and reinstalling these drivers can resolve battery detection issues, incorrect charge readings, and power management problems.

Request you to please follow the below steps to uninstall Battery Drivers:

  • Step 1: Open Device Manager.
  • Step 2: Expand the 'Batteries' category.
  • Step 3: Right-click on each device listed under Batteries (typically 'Microsoft AC Adapter' and 'Microsoft ACPI-Compliant Control Method Battery').
  • Step 4: Select 'Uninstall device' from the context menu.
  • Step 5: After uninstalling both drivers, restart your PC.

Once completed, request you to please check if the battery is working properly after the restart and share the results in the chat.

7.2 Device Manager - Uninstall Speaker Driver

Speaker drivers control audio output functionality. Reinstalling these drivers can fix issues like no sound, distorted audio, low volume, or speakers not being recognized by the system.

Request you to please follow the below steps to uninstall Speaker Driver:

  • Step 1: Open Device Manager.
  • Step 2: In the Device Manager window, expand the Audio inputs and outputs category.
  • Step 3: Right-click on Speaker listed under Audio inputs and outputs.
  • Step 4: Select Uninstall device from the context menu.
  • Step 5: After uninstalling the driver, restart your PC.
  • Step 6: Check if the Speaker is working properly after the restart.

Once completed, request you to please test your speakers and share the results in the chat.

7.3 Device Manager - Uninstall Microphone Driver

Microphone drivers enable audio input recording. Reinstalling these drivers can resolve issues like microphone not being detected, poor audio quality, or recording problems during calls and voice commands.

Request you to please follow the below steps to uninstall Microphone Driver:

  • Step 1: Open Device Manager.
  • Step 2: In the Device Manager window, expand the Audio inputs and outputs category.
  • Step 3: Right-click on Microphone listed under Audio inputs and outputs.
  • Step 4: Select Uninstall device from the context menu.
  • Step 5: After uninstalling the driver, restart your PC.
  • Step 6: Check if the Mic is working properly after the restart.

Once completed, request you to please test your microphone and share the results in the chat.

7.4 Device Manager - Uninstall Fingerprint Driver

Fingerprint drivers manage biometric authentication. Reinstalling these drivers can fix issues with fingerprint recognition, login failures, or the sensor not responding to touch.

Request you to please follow the below steps to uninstall Fingerprint Driver:

  • Step 1: Open Device Manager.
  • Step 2: In the Device Manager window, expand the 'Biometric devices' category.
  • Step 3: Right-click on the driver listed under 'Biometric devices'.
  • Step 4: Select 'Uninstall device' from the context menu.
  • Step 5: After uninstalling the driver, restart your PC.
  • Step 6: Check if the fingerprint sensor is working properly after the restart.

Once completed, request you to please test your fingerprint sensor and share the results in the chat.

7.5 Device Manager - Uninstall Bluetooth Driver

Bluetooth drivers enable wireless connectivity with devices like headphones, mice, and keyboards. Reinstalling these drivers can resolve pairing issues, connection drops, or Bluetooth not being detected.

Request you to please follow the below steps to uninstall Bluetooth Driver:

  • Step 1: Open Device Manager.
  • Step 2: In the Device Manager window, expand the 'Bluetooth' category.
  • Step 3: Right-click on the driver listed under 'Bluetooth'.
  • Step 4: Select 'Uninstall device' from the context menu.
  • Step 5: After uninstalling the driver, restart your PC.
  • Step 6: Check if Bluetooth is working properly after the restart.

Once completed, request you to please test Bluetooth connectivity and share the results in the chat.

7.6 Device Manager - Uninstall Camera Driver

Camera drivers control webcam functionality for video calls and photos. Reinstalling these drivers can fix issues like camera not working, poor video quality, or applications not detecting the camera.

Request you to please follow the below steps to uninstall Camera Driver:

  • Step 1: Open Device Manager.
  • Step 2: In the Device Manager window, expand the Camera category.
  • Step 3: Right-click on the Driver listed under Camera.
  • Step 4: Select Uninstall device from the context menu.
  • Step 5: After uninstalling the driver, restart your PC.
  • Step 6: Check if the Camera is working properly after the restart.

Once completed, request you to please test your camera and share the results in the chat.

7.7 Device Manager - Uninstall Graphic Driver

Graphics drivers control display output and visual performance. Reinstalling these drivers can resolve screen flickering, resolution issues, poor performance, or display not working properly.

Request you to please follow the below steps to uninstall Graphic Driver:

  • Step 1: Open Device Manager.
  • Step 2: In the Device Manager window, expand the Display adaptors category.
  • Step 3: Right-click on the Driver listed under Display adaptors.
  • Step 4: Select Uninstall device from the context menu.
  • Step 5: After uninstalling the driver, restart your PC.
  • Step 6: Check if the Display is working properly after the restart.

Once completed, request you to please test your display quality and share the results in the chat.

7.8 Device Manager - Uninstall Keyboard Driver

Keyboard drivers manage key input functionality. Reinstalling these drivers can fix issues like keys not responding, incorrect characters being typed, or special function keys not working.

Request you to please follow the below steps to uninstall Keyboard Driver:

  • Step 1: Open Device Manager.
  • Step 2: In the Device Manager window, expand the Keyboards category.
  • Step 3: Right-click on the Driver listed under Keyboards.
  • Step 4: Select Uninstall device from the context menu.
  • Step 5: After uninstalling the driver, restart your PC.
  • Step 6: Check if the Keyboard is working properly after the restart.

Once completed, request you to please test your keyboard functionality and share the results in the chat.

7.9 Device Manager - Uninstall Touchpad Driver

Touchpad drivers control cursor movement and gesture recognition. Reinstalling these drivers can resolve issues like touchpad not responding, erratic cursor movement, or gestures not working.

Request you to please follow the below steps to uninstall Touchpad Driver:

  • Step 1: Open Device Manager.
  • Step 2: In the Device Manager window, expand the Mice and other pointing devices category.
  • Step 3: Right-click on the Driver listed under Mice and other pointing devices.
  • Step 4: Select Uninstall device from the context menu.
  • Step 5: After uninstalling the driver, restart your PC.
  • Step 6: Check if the Touchpad is working properly after the restart.

Once completed, request you to please test your touchpad and share the results in the chat.

7.10 Device Manager - Uninstall Wi-Fi Driver

Wi-Fi drivers enable wireless internet connectivity. Reinstalling these drivers can fix connection issues, slow speeds, frequent disconnections, or Wi-Fi networks not being detected.

Request you to please follow the below steps to uninstall Wi-Fi Driver:

  • Step 1: Open Device Manager.
  • Step 2: In the Device Manager window, expand the Network adapters category.
  • Step 3: Check for the Wifi card shipped with unit Example(Intel, Realtech etc) .
  • Step 4: Select Uninstall device from the context menu.
  • Step 5: After uninstalling the driver, restart your PC.
  • Step 6: Check if the Wi-Fi is working properly after the restart.

Once completed, request you to please test your Wi-Fi connection and share the results in the chat.

7.11 Device Manager - Uninstall Mouse Driver

Mouse drivers control external mouse functionality and precision. Reinstalling these drivers can resolve issues like mouse not being detected, buttons not working, or cursor movement problems.

Request you to please follow the below steps to uninstall Mouse Driver:

  • Step 1: Open Device Manager.
  • Step 2: In the Device Manager window, expand the 'Mice and other pointing devices' category.
  • Step 3: Right-click on the driver for your mouse.
  • Step 4: Select 'Uninstall device' from the context menu.
  • Step 5: After uninstalling the driver, restart your PC.
  • Step 6: Check if the Mouse is working properly after the restart.

Once completed, request you to please test your mouse functionality and share the results in the chat.

7.12 Device Manager - Uninstall Touch Screen Driver

Touch screen drivers enable direct screen interaction through touch. Reinstalling these drivers can fix issues like touch not responding, inaccurate touch detection, or gestures not working properly.

Request you to please follow the below steps to uninstall Touch Screen Driver:

  • Step 1: Open Device Manager.
  • Step 2: In the Device Manager window, expand the 'Human Interface Devices' category.
  • Step 3: Right-click on the 'HID-compliant touch screen' driver.
  • Step 4: Select 'Uninstall device' from the context menu.
  • Step 5: After uninstalling the driver, restart your PC.
  • Step 6: Check if the Touch Screen is working properly after the restart.

Once completed, request you to please test your touch screen functionality and share the results in the chat.

7.13 Device Manager - Uninstall Ethernet/LAN Driver

Ethernet/LAN drivers enable wired internet connectivity. Reinstalling these drivers can resolve connection issues, slow wired internet speeds, or the network port not being recognized.

Request you to please follow the below steps to uninstall Ethernet/LAN Driver:

  • Step 1: Open Device Manager.
  • Step 2: In the Device Manager window, expand the 'Network adapters' category.
  • Step 3: Right-click on your wired Ethernet/LAN adapter.
  • Step 4: Select 'Uninstall device' from the context menu.
  • Step 5: After uninstalling the driver, restart your PC.
  • Step 6: Check if the Ethernet connection is working properly after the restart.

Once completed, request you to please test your wired internet connection and share the results in the chat.

7.14 Device Manager - Uninstall Disk Drive

Disk drive management controls storage device recognition and performance. Reinstalling these drivers can fix issues like drives not being detected, slow performance, or file access problems.

Request you to please follow the below steps to uninstall Disk Drive:

  • Step 1: Open Device Manager.
  • Step 2: In the Device Manager window, expand the 'Disk drives' category.
  • Step 3: Right-click on your primary SSD or HDD.
  • Step 4: Select 'Uninstall device' from the context menu.
  • Step 5: After uninstalling the device, restart your PC.
  • Step 6: Windows will automatically reinstall the necessary drivers on restart.

Once completed, request you to please check your storage drive performance and share the results in the chat.

7.15 Device Manager - Uninstall USB Controllers

USB controllers manage all USB port functionality and device communication. Reinstalling these drivers can resolve issues like USB devices not being recognized, ports not working, or connection problems.

Request you to please follow the below steps to uninstall USB Controllers:

  • Step 1: Open Device Manager.
  • Step 2: In the Device Manager window, expand the 'Universal Serial Bus controllers' category.
  • Step 3: Right-click on the main 'Host Controller' or 'Root Hub' entries.
  • Step 4: Select 'Uninstall device' from the context menu for each one.
  • Step 5: After uninstalling, restart your PC.
  • Step 6: Check if your USB ports are working properly after the restart.

Once completed, request you to please test your USB ports with various devices and share the results in the chat.

7.16 Device Manager - Uninstall Sound Controller

Sound controller drivers manage all audio input and output functions. Reinstalling these drivers can fix comprehensive audio issues, including no sound, poor quality, or audio devices not being recognized.

Request you to please follow the below steps to uninstall Sound Controller Driver:

  • Step 1: Open Device Manager.
  • Step 2: In the Device Manager window, expand the 'Sound, video and game controllers' category.
  • Step 3: Right-click on your main audio device (e.g., Realtek High Definition Audio).
  • Step 4: Select 'Uninstall device' from the context menu.
  • Step 5: After uninstalling the driver, restart your PC.
  • Step 6: Check if audio is working properly after the restart.

Once completed, request you to please test all audio functions and share the results in the chat.

7.17 Device Manager - Uninstall Processors

Processor management controls CPU recognition and performance optimization. Reinstalling these drivers can resolve performance issues, thermal management problems, or processor cores not being detected properly.

Request you to please follow the below steps to uninstall Processors:

  • Step 1: Open Device Manager.
  • Step 2: In the Device Manager window, expand the 'Processors' category.
  • Step 3: Right-click on each processor core listed.
  • Step 4: Select 'Uninstall device' from the context menu.
  • Step 5: After uninstalling, restart your PC.
  • Step 6: The processors will be re-detected and reinstalled automatically.

Once completed, request you to please check system performance and share the results in the chat.

8.1 Windows Reset - From Settings

Please follow the below steps to reset the Windows.

  • • Type and search Reset this PC in the Windows search bar, then click Open.
  • • In the Reset this PC menu, click Reset PC.
  • • Select Keep my files.
  • • Choose Local reinstall.
  • • Click Change settings.
  • • Set the option Restore apps and settings which came with this PC to Yes, then select Confirm.
  • • Confirm that the settings are correct, then click Next.
  • • You may receive a notification; select Next to continue the reset process.
  • • Select Reset.

8.2 Windows Reset - From BIOS

Please use the below steps to reset the windows from BIOS.

  • • Shutdown the computer
  • • Press the power button once again and immediately tap ESC key multiple times. Thereafter you will see the Start-up Options, press F11
  • • On the Choose an option screen, click Troubleshoot.
  • • Select Reset PC.
  • • Select Remove everything.
  • • Select Local reinstall.
  • • Then select Next.
  • • Click on Reset to start the process.

9.1 OS Re-installation - Requirements

Requirements:

  • • 32 GB pen drive.
  • • Working computer.
  • • Backup your data before proceeding.

9.2 OS Re-installation - Media Creation Only

Steps to reinstall Windows using the Microsoft Media Creation Tool should be performed on another working computer.

Please find the link for the Microsoft Creation Tool:

For specific PC support, please refer to:

  • **Windows 11:** https://www.microsoft.com/en-in/software-download/windows11
  • **Windows 10:** https://www.microsoft.com/en-in/software-download/windows10

Follow the instructions under the section 'Using the tool to create installation media'.

  • •Select Download tool now, and select Run. You need to be an administrator to run this tool..
  • • Select 'Download tool now', and then select 'Run'. You must be an administrator to run this tool.
  • • If you agree to the license terms, select Accept.
  • • On the What do you want to do? page, select Create installation media for another PC, and then select Next.
  • • Select Windows 11.
  • • Select which media you want to use:
  • • USB flash drive. Attach a blank USB flash drive with at least 8GB of space. Any content on the flash drive will be deleted.
  • •After the installation media is created, follow the steps below to use it.

Please let me know once the above steps are completed.

9.3 OS Re-installation - Media Creation(Post Media Creation)

Now take the flash drive/pen drive/hard disk and plug it into the computer where you want to reinstall the OS. Then follow the steps below:

  • • Insert the USB boot device you created, and then turn off the computer.
  • • Turn on the computer and immediately press the Esc key repeatedly (about once every second) until the Startup Menu opens.
  • • Press the F9 key to open Boot Device Options.
  • • Use the arrow keys to select the USB drive, and then press Enter.
  • • When prompted to run Recovery Manager from the hard drive or from media, select 'Run program from media', and click Next.
  • • Select a language, and then click OK.
  • • Select 'Factory Reset', and then click Next.
  • • On the Welcome screen, click Next.
  • • Select 'Recover without backing up your files', and then click Next.
  • • Wait while HP Recovery Manager prepares the system and copies the files to the hard drive.
  • • Click Skip when asked if you received a supplemental recovery USB drive from HP Support.
  • • Click Continue once recovery preparation is complete.
  • • Do not remove the USB drive or power off the PC during the process. The system may go through several screens including black screens, HP logo, and Windows setup—this is normal.
  • • After recovery is complete, click Finish to restart the system.
  • • You can remove the USB flash drive once the initial setup begins.

9.4 OS Re-installation - HP Cloud Recovery Client(Complete Steps)

This process uses another computer to create a USB recovery drive, which will reinstall the original operating system on your HP computer.

Part 1: What You Need Before You Start

  • • A different, working Windows computer with a stable internet connection.
  • • A blank USB flash drive with at least 32 GB of space. Warning: All data on this drive will be permanently erased.
  • • The serial number of the HP computer you need to recover.

Part 2: Creating the Recovery USB Drive (On the working PC)

  1. 1. On the working computer, download and install the HP Cloud Recovery Tool (link at the bottom).
  2. 2. Open the installed HP Cloud Recovery Tool.
  3. 3. The tool will guide you. You will need to enter the serial number of the computer you are fixing so it can download the correct software.
  4. 4. Follow the prompts until it asks you to select a USB drive. Insert your 32 GB USB drive and select it from the dropdown list.
  5. 5. You must accept the warning that all data on the USB drive will be deleted.
  6. 6. The tool will now download the recovery image and create the recovery drive. This is a long process; please let it complete without interruption.

Part 3: Recovering Your Computer (On the computer that needs fixing)

  1. 1. Once the recovery USB drive has been created, safely eject it from the working PC.
  2. 2. Take the USB drive to the computer you need to fix and plug it in while the computer is turned off.
  3. 3. Turn on the computer and immediately press the Esc key repeatedly until the Startup Menu appears.
  4. 4. From the Startup Menu, press the F9 key to open the Boot Device Options.
  5. 5. Select your USB flash drive from the list and press Enter. The system will now boot into the HP Recovery Manager.
  6. 6. Choose the Factory Reset option to completely erase the hard drive and reinstall Windows.
  7. 7.
    Crucial Warning: You must agree to all prompts confirming that you understand all personal files, applications, and data will be permanently lost. This action cannot be undone.
  8. 8. The recovery will now begin. The computer will restart several times; this is normal. Make sure the computer stays plugged into a power source and do not turn it off.
  9. 9. Once it's finished, your computer will boot into the initial Windows setup screen, just like a brand new PC.

  • **Business PC:** https://support.hp.com/us-en/document/ish_4374279-4216685-16
  • **Consumer PC:** https://support.hp.com/us-en/document/ish_4511095-4511141-16

    • 10. HPSA Updates(Consumer Units)

    Open HP Support Assistant:

    • • Press Windows and type HP Support Assistant, then open the app.
    • • Check for Updates: On the My Dashboard tab, find your device and click Updates. (If no updates are seen, select the refresh icon on the top.) Click 'Check for updates and messages'.
    • • Install Updates: Review available updates (drivers, BIOS, etc.). Select what you need and click Install.
    • • Restart: If prompted, restart your PC to complete the installation.

    HP Image Assistant (HPIA - Commercial Units)

    1. 1. https://support.hp.com/za-en/document/ish_7636709-7636753-16
      Please follow the above link as it has the detailed step on how to download HPIA and have the pending updates done.
    2. 2. Please click on Analyze, as it analyzes the unit and recommends the pending drivers which are to be updated for your unit.
    3. 3. Please click on the recommendations and it will show the drivers which are to be installed, request you to please install all the drivers.

    11. Windows Updates

    Please perform the steps below to check for pending Windows updates:

    • • Open Settings.
    • • Go to 'Update & Security'.
    • • Click 'Windows Update'.
    • • Click 'Check for updates' and install everything available.
    • • Restart your PC after installation.

    12. Battery Calibration

    Calibrating your battery improves the accuracy of its life indicator. Below are two methods to do this. The first method using HP's built-in tools is recommended for best results.

    Method 1: Using HP Diagnostic Tools (Recommended)

    Part 1: Discharging the Battery

    1. 1. Disconnect the AC power adapter.
    2. 2. Press and hold the power button for five seconds to ensure the computer is fully off.
    3. 3. Turn the computer on and immediately press the Esc key repeatedly (about once per second).
    4. 4. When the Startup Menu appears, press the F2 key to open the HP PC Hardware Diagnostics menu.
    5. 5. In the main menu, click Component Tests, then select Battery.
    6. 6. On the Battery Test page, click Run once. After the initial test, click Calibrate Battery.
    7. 7. On the next screen, click Start Calibration and follow any on-screen prompts.

    The tool will now drain the battery, which can take several hours. The PC will shut down automatically when finished.

    Part 2: Recharging the Battery

    1. 1. Once the computer has shut itself off, plug the AC adapter back in.
    2. 2. Let the battery charge fully to 100%. This typically takes about 4 hours. Do not use the computer during this period.
    3. 3. After the battery reaches 100%, keep it plugged in and wait for 2 more hours before using it.

    The battery is now calibrated. For a visual guide, please also refer to this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OBJxM5HQFs0

    Method 2: Basic Manual Cycle

    1. 1. Charge to 100%: Fully charge the laptop battery to 100%.
    2. 2. Discharge to 0%: Unplug the charger and use the laptop normally until the battery drains completely and the laptop shuts down on its own.
    3. 3. Recharge Fully: Plug the charger back in and let the battery fully recharge to 100%, ideally without turning the laptop on.
    4. 4. Power On: Once it's fully charged, you can turn on and use the laptop.
    5. 5. Repeat: For best results, it is recommended to repeat this full charge/discharge process upto 3 times.

    IDR Logs

    I will need the IDR logs of the unit to investigate further.

    Please refer to the below link to generate the IDR logs:
    https://ftp.hp.com/pub/idr/ImageDiags3/ImageDiags.exe

    Steps to be followed:

    • • Copy the link to the browser.
    • • Download the .exe file.
    • • Once done, double-click on the file to run it. Click on "Y" to begin the program.
    • • You would be asked to generate a report, mention "n" and hit enter to continue with the IDR logs taking.
    • • Once done the program will close automatically and create a file by the name "IDR_Serial number.ZIP".
    • • Please save the files to one drive or google drive and help me with a link.

    14. HP Support Page

    HP Support Website Instructions:

    • • Go to https://support.hp.com/gb-en
    • • Scroll down to find the device search bar.
    • • Enter your device serial number.
    • • Select 'Software and Drivers'.
    • • If prompted, identify your OS version (you can find this by typing 'winver' in the Windows search bar).
    • • Download the latest drivers listed.
    • • Install them and restart your PC.

    15. Battery Health Report

    Generate Battery Health Report:

    • • Open Command Prompt as administrator.
    • • Run: powercfg /batteryreport
    • • The report will be saved at: C:\\WINDOWS\\system32\\battery-report.html

    Once generated, please share the report via email.

    16. Recovery Key

    If your computer is asking for a BitLocker recovery key, it is likely backed up to your Microsoft account. To find it, you will need to use a separate device (like a phone or another computer) with internet access.

    Step 1: Get the Key from Your Microsoft Account

    1. 1. On your other device, open a web browser and go to: https://aka.ms/myrecoverykey
    2. 2. Sign in using the same Microsoft account email and password that you use on your locked computer.
    3. 3. You should now see a list of recovery keys registered to your account.

    Step 2: Find the Correct Key

    Your locked computer's screen shows a Recovery Key ID. On the website, find the key that has a matching Device Name. This is to make sure you use the right key for the right computer.

    Step 3: Enter the Key

    1. 1. Once you have identified the correct 48-digit key, carefully type it into the prompt on your locked computer.
    2. 2. Select Continue to unlock your device.

    17. BIOS Defaults

    Restoring the BIOS to its factory settings can help resolve certain issues. Please follow the steps for your type of notebook below.

    For HP Consumer Notebooks (e.g., Pavilion, Envy, Spectre)

    Method 1: Using the BIOS Menu

    1. 1. Turn off the computer completely.
    2. 2. Press the power button, then immediately tap the F10 key repeatedly until the BIOS setup menu appears.
    3. 3. Use the arrow keys to navigate to the Exit tab.
    4. 4. Select Load Setup Defaults and press Enter.
    5. 5. When prompted, select Yes to confirm. The computer will restart.

    Method 2: Using a Key Combination

    1. 1. Turn off the computer and make sure the AC adapter is plugged in.
    2. 2. Press and hold the Windows + v keys at the same time.
    3. 3. While holding those keys, press and release the power button.
    4. 4. Continue holding Windows + v until a message about a CMOS reset or BIOS recovery appears.
    5. 5. Press Enter to restart the computer.

    For HP Commercial Notebooks (e.g., ProBook, EliteBook, ZBook)

    1. 1. Turn off the computer completely.
    2. 2. Press the power button, then immediately tap the F10 key repeatedly until the BIOS setup menu appears.
    3. 3. Using the arrow keys, navigate to the Main tab.
    4. 4. Select Restore Defaults and press Enter.
    5. 5. When prompted, select Yes to confirm.
    6. 6. Navigate back to the Main tab, select Save Changes and Exit, and press Enter.
    7. 7. Select Yes again to save the settings and restart.

    You can also follow the instructions in this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6woHPW-GB-E

    18. Safe Mode

    SAFE MODE (Standard Method):

    • • Press Win + I to open Settings.
    • • Go to System > Recovery.
    • • Click Restart now under Advanced startup.
    • • After restart, select Troubleshoot.
    • • Choose Advanced options.
    • • Click Startup Settings.
    • • Click Restart.
    • • Press 4 or F4 for Safe Mode or 5 or F5 for Safe Mode with Networking.

    19.1 General Information & Definitions)

    BIOS / UEFI

    BIOS (Basic Input/Output System) or UEFI (Unified Extensible Firmware Interface) is the first software that runs when you turn on your computer. It initializes the hardware (like your keyboard, hard drive, and memory) before loading the main operating system (like Windows).

    BitLocker Recovery Key

    A BitLocker Recovery Key is a 48-digit password used to unlock your hard drive if Windows detects a potential security risk (like a major hardware or BIOS change). It is automatically generated and usually saved to the Microsoft account associated with the computer.

    CMOS Reset

    A CMOS Reset clears the very basic hardware configuration settings stored on a small memory chip on the motherboard. This is a deeper reset than restoring BIOS defaults and can resolve issues where the computer fails to power on or initialize hardware correctly.

    Driver

    A Driver is a special piece of software that allows your operating system (Windows) to communicate with and control a piece of hardware (like a graphics card, printer, or webcam). Outdated or corrupt drivers are a common cause of issues.

    Hard Reset / Power Drain

    A Hard Reset or Power Drain is the process of completely disconnecting all power sources from the computer and holding the power button to discharge any residual electricity from the internal components. This simple step can resolve many issues related to freezing, booting, or hardware not being detected.

    OSRI (Operating System Re-installation)

    OSRI is the process of completely erasing the hard drive and reinstalling the operating system. This is also known as a "Factory Reset." It returns the computer to the state it was in when it was first purchased. All personal data, programs, and settings will be permanently lost.

    Safe Mode

    Safe Mode is a diagnostic mode that starts Windows with only the most essential drivers and services. If an issue doesn't happen in Safe Mode, it strongly suggests the problem is caused by third-party software or a non-essential driver, not the core hardware or Windows itself.

    System Reset (Keep Files)

    A System Reset (Keep Files) reinstalls the Windows operating system but keeps your personal files (documents, photos, etc.). However, it will remove all applications and programs you have installed (like Microsoft Office, Chrome, games, etc.).

    System Restore

    A System Restore rolls back Windows system files, drivers, and settings to an earlier point in time (a "restore point"). It does not affect your personal files, but it will uninstall any apps or drivers that were installed *after* the restore point was created.

    Temp Files

    Temp Files (Temporary Files) are created by programs and the operating system to hold information while a task is being performed. Over time, these can build up and take up space. Deleting them is generally safe and will not result in any personal data loss.

    19.2 Common Boot Errors


    3F0 HDD errors NON-System disk error Bootmgr missing error Invalid system disk error Black screen with blinking cursor No Operating system found Unit freezes at HP logo Black screen after HP logo

    + Initial Assessment & Information Gathering (For Agent)

    [AGENT SCRIPT]:

    I understand your HP laptop isn't booting up correctly, and you're seeing an error message. I know how frustrating this can be, but I'm here to help you troubleshoot it step-by-step.
    To help me best assist you, could you please tell me:

    1. On what screen does the laptop restart? (e.g., during Windows loading, at the desktop, in BIOS)
    2. Does it restart while using a specific application, or even when the system is idle?
    3. How often does it restart? Do you see any pattern, like after a certain amount of time?

    • **[AGENT ACTION]:** While waiting for the customer's response, use the serial number/model provided by the customer to identify if it's an **HP Consumer** or **HP Commercial** model.

    [AGENT SCRIPT - If Commercial Model]:

    "Thank you for that. Since it's a Commercial model, may I ask if this is a company-issued laptop? (If so, please remind the customer that their IT department might have specific procedures for their device.)"

    + HP CONSUMER Notebooks (Pavilion, Envy, Spectre etc)

    *(Agent: Use this section if the laptop is an HP Consumer Model.)*

    + 1. Perform a Hard Reset (Power Drain)

    [Agent Script]:

    Okay, thank you for that information. Let's start with a crucial first step called a 'Hard Reset' or 'Power Drain'. This helps clear any temporary electrical glitches that might be preventing your laptop from starting.

    Please follow these steps carefully:
    1. **Shut down your laptop completely.** If it's frozen, press and hold the power button until it turns off.
    2. **Disconnect the AC adapter (charger) from your laptop.**
    3. **Disconnect all external devices** connected to your laptop – this includes any USB drives, external monitors, printers, etc.
    4. Now, **press and hold the power button on your laptop for about 25-30 seconds.** This helps drain any leftover power.
    5. After 25-30 seconds, **reconnect ONLY the AC adapter** to the laptop.
    6. Try to **turn on your laptop**. Please let me know the outcome once this is done.

    + 2. Check Boot Order in BIOS

    [Agent Script]:

    Alright, if the hard reset didn't fix it, let's check your laptop's 'Boot Order' in the BIOS. This tells your laptop which device to load the operating system from.

    Please try this:
    1. **Shut down your laptop again.**
    2. **Press the power button**, and immediately start tapping the **F10 key repeatedly** (don't hold it) until you see the BIOS Setup Utility screen. It usually has a blue or gray background.
    3. Once in BIOS, use your arrow keys to navigate. Look for an option like **'Boot Options'** (it might be under 'Advanced' or 'System Configuration').
    4. Inside 'Boot Options', find 'Boot Order' or 'Boot Device Priority'.
    5. **Make sure 'OS Boot Manager' (or your Hard Drive/SSD) is listed first.** If something else like a USB drive or Network Boot is first, use the on-screen instructions (usually F5/F6 or +/- keys) to move 'OS Boot Manager' to the top.
    6. Once you've adjusted the order, find the 'Exit' menu (often F10 to save and exit) and **save the changes**. Your laptop should then restart. Please let me know the outcome once this is done.

    + 3. Check Secure Boot Configuration

    [Agent Script]:

    Okay, if the boot order wasn't the issue, let's check the 'Secure Boot' setting in the BIOS. Incorrect settings here can sometimes prevent Windows from loading.

    Please try this:
    1. **In the BIOS (F10 key, if you're not already there), navigate to 'Secure Boot Configuration'** (often under 'Security' or 'Boot Options').
    2. Ensure **"Legacy Support Disabled"** and **"Secure Boot Enabled"**. If these settings were different, please change them to this configuration.
    3. Save changes and Exit. Your laptop will restart. Please let me know the outcome once this is done.

    + 4. Test the Hard Drive/SSD using HP PC Hardware Diagnostics UEFI

    [Agent Script]:

    If your laptop still isn't booting, the next crucial step is to test the hard drive (or SSD) itself. HP has a built-in diagnostic tool for this.

    Please try this:
    1. **Shut down your laptop.**
    2. **Press the power button**, and immediately start tapping the **F2 key repeatedly** (don't hold it) until you see the HP PC Hardware Diagnostics UEFI screen.
    3. From the menu, choose **'Component Tests'** > **'Storage'** > **'HDD/SSD'**.
    4. Select the **'Quick Test'** option and let it run.
    5. **What was the result of the Quick Test?** Did it Pass or Fail? If it failed, please tell me the 24-digit Failure ID if you see one. I'll wait for your confirmation on the outcome.

    [AGENT HINT for Internal Use]:

    • If Test Fails: A failed HDD/SSD test directly indicates the Storage Drive (HDD/SSD) is faulty. This will require a replacement. Guide customer about hardware failure and check Pre-tool for recommended part number for Storage Drive (HDD/SSD) replacement.
    • If Test Passes: The storage hardware is likely fine. Proceed to the next step.

    + 5. Test for Corrupt Operating System (Windows Recovery Environment - F11)

    [Agent Script]:

    Since the hardware test passed (or if we need to rule out software issues), it's possible your Windows Operating System has become corrupted. HP laptops have a built-in recovery environment that can help with this.

    Please try to access the Windows Recovery Environment:
    1. **Shut down your laptop.**
    2. **Press the power button**, and immediately start tapping the **F11 key repeatedly** (don't hold it) until you see the 'Choose an option' screen (it usually has a blue background).
    3. Once on that screen, click on **'Troubleshoot'**.
    4. **What options do you see after clicking 'Troubleshoot'?** (e.g., 'Reset this PC', 'Advanced options'). Please let me know what options appear on your screen.

    [Agent Script]: "Alright, let's try these options in order:

    A. Boot to Safe Mode:

    This loads a minimal version of Windows.
    1. From 'Troubleshoot', select **'Advanced options' > 'Startup Settings' > 'Restart'**.
    2. On the next screen, tap **F5** to select **'Safe Mode with Networking'**.
    3. **If it boots into Safe Mode:** This means Windows can load in a basic state. We'll try to disable conflicting programs.
    * In Safe Mode, click the Start button, type `msconfig` in the search bar, and select 'System Configuration'. (Alternatively, press **Windows key + R**, type `msconfig`, and press Enter).
    * Go to the **'Services' tab**. Check 'Hide all Microsoft services'. Click 'Disable all'. Apply, OK, and Restart your laptop normally. If it boots, a program was causing the issue.
    4. **If it does NOT boot to Safe Mode:** Please let me know, and we'll move to the next option (System Restore).

    B. System Restore:

    This tries to revert your system files to an earlier time when it was working, without affecting your personal files.
    1. From 'Troubleshoot', select **'Advanced options' > 'System Restore'**.
    2. Follow the prompts to select a restore point and start the process.
    3. **After it completes:** Please let me know if your laptop boots normally. If not, we'll proceed to the next option (System Reset).

    C. System Reset (Keep My Files):

    This reinstalls Windows, but attempts to keep your personal files. All installed applications will be removed.
    1. From 'Troubleshoot', select **'Reset this PC' > 'Keep my files'**.
    2. **Important:** While this tries to keep files, it's always safest to have a backup if possible.
    3. Follow the on-screen prompts.
    4. **After it completes:** Please let me know if your laptop boots normally. If not, we'll proceed to the final option (Full OS Reinstallation).

    D. OS Reinstallation (Remove Everything):

    This is a last resort and will completely erase all data on your hard drive.

    [Agent Script - CRITICAL WARNING]: "Before proceeding, it's *extremely important* to understand that **this step will erase ALL data on your hard drive.** If you have any personal files, photos, or documents that are not backed up, they will be lost. Do you have a recent backup, or is data loss acceptable to proceed?"

    Okay, understood. To proceed with a full OS reinstallation, you have two main methods:

    Method 1 (F11 Recovery - Easiest if it works):
    1. From 'Troubleshoot', select **'Reset this PC' > 'Remove everything'**.
    2. Follow the prompts to proceed.

    Method 2 (USB Recovery Media - If F11 fails or preferred):
    1. On another working PC, please go to **HP's support website** and search for 'HP Cloud Recovery Client'. This tool helps you create a USB drive with the exact factory image for your specific HP model. You'll need your serial number.
    2. Alternatively, you can search for **'Windows Media Creation Tool'** on Microsoft's website. This tool lets you create a bootable USB drive with the latest Windows version.
    3. Once you have the USB drive, plug it into your problematic laptop, then restart and repeatedly tap **F9** (for Boot Device Options). Select the USB drive to boot from it and follow the installation prompts.

    The system will load back to factory settings. Please let me know the outcome once this is complete.

    + 7. Escalation for Hardware Replacement (if applicable)

    [AGENT HINT for Internal Use]:

    • If Step 4 (HDD/SSD Test) FAILED with a Failure ID: The Storage Drive (HDD/SSD) is faulty.
    • If all OS steps (Step 5) failed and the issue persists: It's highly likely a Motherboard issue.
    • ACTION: Before advising replacement, always double-check the identified faulty part (e.g., HDD/SSD, Motherboard) with your Pre-tool to confirm the recommended part for replacement.

    + HP COMMERCIAL Notebooks (EliteBook, ProBook, ZBook etc)

    *(Agent: Use this section if the laptop is an HP Commercial Model.)*

    + 1. Perform a Hard Reset (Power Drain)

    [Agent Script]:

    Okay, thank you for that information. Let's start with a crucial first step called a 'Hard Reset' or 'Power Drain'. This helps clear any temporary electrical glitches that might be preventing your laptop from starting.

    Please follow these steps carefully:
    1. **Shut down your laptop completely.** If it's frozen, press and hold the power button until it turns off.
    2. **Disconnect the AC adapter (charger) from your laptop.**
    3. **Disconnect all external devices** connected to your laptop – this includes any USB drives, external monitors, printers, etc.
    4. Now, **press and hold the power button on your laptop for about 25-30 seconds.** This helps drain any leftover power.
    5. After 25-30 seconds, **reconnect ONLY the AC adapter** to the laptop.
    6. Try to **turn on your laptop**. Please let me know the outcome once this is done.

    + 2. Test the Hard Drive/SSD using HP PC Hardware Diagnostics UEFI

    [Agent Script]:

    If your laptop still isn't booting, the next crucial step is to test the hard drive (or SSD) itself. HP has a very robust built-in diagnostic tool for this.

    Please try this:
    1. **Shut down your laptop.**
    2. **Press the power button**, and immediately start tapping the **F2 key repeatedly** (don't hold it) until you see the HP PC Hardware Diagnostics UEFI screen.
    3. From the menu, choose **'Component Tests'** > **'Storage'** > **'HDD/SSD'**.
    4. Select the **'Quick Test'** option and let it run.
    5. **What was the result of the Quick Test?** Did it Pass or Fail? If it failed, please tell me the 24-digit Failure ID if you see one. I'll wait for your confirmation on the outcome.

    [AGENT HINT for Internal Use]:

    • If Test Fails: A failed HDD/SSD test directly indicates the Storage Drive (HDD/SSD) is faulty. This will require a replacement. Guide customer about hardware failure and check Pre-tool for recommended part number for Storage Drive (HDD/SSD) replacement.
    • If Test Passes: The storage hardware is likely fine. Proceed to the next step.

    + 3. Check Secure Boot Configuration & HP Sure Start

    [Agent Script]:

    Okay, if the boot order wasn't the issue, let's check the 'Secure Boot' setting in the BIOS. Commercial models like yours have advanced security features, and incorrect settings can prevent Windows from loading.

    Please try this:
    1. **In the BIOS (F10 key, if you're not already there), navigate to 'Secure Boot Configuration'** (often under 'Security' or 'Boot Options').
    2. Ensure **"Legacy Support Disabled"** and **"Secure Boot Enabled"** for standard Windows operation. If these settings were different, please change them to this configuration.
    3. **Regarding HP Sure Start:** If you encountered "HP Sure Start" errors, "HP Endpoint Security Controller" messages, or the laptop freezes after a security message, this indicates a BIOS integrity check. Allow the Sure Start process to complete. Persistent issues here might point to a need for a BIOS update (see Step 6).
    4. **Important:** If this is a company-issued laptop, please be aware that your IT department might have locked these settings or have specific policies. Avoid making changes without their guidance if unsure.
    5. Save changes and Exit. Your laptop will restart. Please let me know the outcome once this is done.

    + 4. Test for Corrupt Operating System (Windows Recovery Environment - F11)

    [Agent Script]:

    Since the hardware test passed (or if we need to rule out software issues), it's possible your Windows Operating System has become corrupted. HP laptops have a built-in recovery environment that can help with this.

    Please try to access the Windows Recovery Environment:
    1. **Shut down your laptop.**
    2. **Press the power button**, and immediately start tapping the **F11 key repeatedly** (don't hold it) until you see the 'Choose an option' screen (it usually has a blue background).
    3. Once on that screen, click on **'Troubleshoot'**.
    4. **What options do you see after clicking 'Troubleshoot'?** (e.g., 'Reset this PC', 'Advanced options'). Please let me know what options appear on your screen.

    [Agent Script]: "Alright, let's try these options in order:

    A. Boot to Safe Mode:

    This loads a minimal version of Windows.
    1. From 'Troubleshoot', select **'Advanced options' > 'Startup Settings' > 'Restart'**.
    2. On the next screen, tap **F5** to select **'Safe Mode with Networking'**.
    3. **If it boots into Safe Mode:** This means Windows can load in a basic state. We'll try to disable conflicting programs.
    * In Safe Mode, click the Start button, type `msconfig` in the search bar, and select 'System Configuration'. (Alternatively, press **Windows key + R**, type `msconfig`, and press Enter).
    * Go to the **'Services' tab**. Check 'Hide all Microsoft services'. Click 'Disable all'. Apply, OK, and Restart your laptop normally. If it boots, a program was causing the issue.
    4. **If it does NOT boot to Safe Mode:** Please let me know, and we'll move to the next option (System Restore).

    B. System Restore:

    This tries to revert your system files to an earlier time when it was working, without affecting your personal files.
    1. From 'Troubleshoot', select **'Advanced options' > 'System Restore'**.
    2. Follow the prompts to select a restore point and start the process.
    3. **After it completes:** Please let me know if your laptop boots normally. If not, we'll proceed to the next option (System Reset).

    C. System Reset (Keep My Files):

    This reinstalls Windows, but attempts to keep your personal files. All installed applications will be removed.
    1. From 'Troubleshoot', select **'Reset this PC' > 'Keep my files'**.
    2. **Important:** If this is a company-issued laptop with BitLocker encryption, you will likely need a recovery key from your IT department. Do not proceed without it if prompted.
    3. Follow the on-screen prompts.
    4. **After it completes:** Please let me know if your laptop boots normally. If not, we'll proceed to the final option (Full OS Reinstallation).

    D. OS Reinstallation (Remove Everything):

    This is a last resort and will completely erase all data on your hard drive.

    [Agent Script - CRITICAL WARNING]: "Before proceeding, it's *extremely important* to understand that **this step will erase ALL data on your hard drive.** If you have any personal files, photos, or documents that are not backed up, they will be lost. Do you have a recent backup, or is data loss acceptable to proceed?"

    [Agent Script - COMPANY LAPTOP WARNING]: "If this is a company-issued laptop, **DO NOT proceed with 'Remove everything'** without first confirming with your IT department. They will have their own secure re-imaging procedures and may need to recover company data."

    Okay, understood. To proceed with a full OS reinstallation, you have two main methods:

    Method 1 (F11 Recovery - Easiest if it works):
    1. From 'Troubleshoot', select **'Reset this PC' > 'Remove everything'**.
    2. Follow the prompts to proceed.

    Method 2 (USB Recovery Media - If F11 fails or preferred):
    1. On another working PC, please go to **HP's business support website:** `support.hp.com/us-en/drivers/business` and search for 'HP Cloud Recovery Client'. This tool helps you create a USB drive with the exact factory image for your specific HP model. You'll need your serial number.
    2. Alternatively, you can search for **'Windows Media Creation Tool'** on Microsoft's website. This tool lets you create a bootable USB drive with the latest Windows version.
    3. Once you have the USB drive, plug it into your problematic laptop, then restart and repeatedly tap **F9** (for Boot Device Options). Select the USB drive to boot from it and follow the installation prompts.

    The system will load back to factory settings. Please let me know the outcome once this is complete.

    + 6. BIOS/Firmware Updates (Specific to Commercial Models)

    [Agent Script]:

    If we've gone through all the previous steps and the issue persists, especially if you saw repeated 'HP Sure Start' or other security-related messages, we should check for a BIOS/Firmware update. Commercial models often receive critical updates that address these types of issues.

    Please try this (you'll need another working computer):
    1. Go to **HP's business support website:** `support.hp.com/us-en/drivers/business`
    2. Enter your **exact commercial model number** to find its support page.
    3. Look for 'BIOS' or 'Firmware' updates.
    4. If a newer version is available, guide the customer to download it. It will usually come with instructions on how to create a bootable USB drive to update the BIOS from outside of Windows (often done via the F2 or F10 BIOS menu, looking for 'Firmware Management' or 'BIOS Update').
    5. **Important:** BIOS updates are critical. The laptop must remain plugged in and fully charged throughout the process. Please let me know the outcome once this is done.

    [AGENT HINT for Internal Use]:

    • If BIOS update fails or does not resolve persistent BIOS/Sure Start issues on a Commercial Model: This often points to a Motherboard replacement being needed.

    + 7. Escalation for Hardware Replacement (if applicable)

    [AGENT HINT for Internal Use]:

    • If Step 4 (HDD/SSD Test) FAILED with a Failure ID: The Storage Drive (HDD/SSD) is faulty.
    • If all OS steps (Step 5) failed and the issue persists, AND especially if there were also persistent BIOS/Sure Start issues (Step 6) or other unusual behavior: It's highly likely a Motherboard issue.
    • ACTION: Before advising replacement, always double-check the identified faulty part (e.g., HDD/SSD, Motherboard) with your Pre-tool to confirm the recommended part for replacement.

    19.4 Unit Restarts Continuously

    + Initial Assessment & Information Gathering (For Agent)

    [AGENT SCRIPT]:

    Hello! I understand your HP laptop is restarting continuously. This can be quite disruptive, but I'm here to help you troubleshoot it step-by-step. To help me best assist you, could you please tell me:
    1. On what screen does the laptop restart? (e.g., during Windows loading, at the desktop, in BIOS)
    2. Does it restart while using a specific application, or even when the system is idle?
    3. How often does it restart? Do you see any pattern, like after a certain amount of time?

    • **[AGENT ACTION]:** While waiting for the customer's response, use the serial number/model provided by the customer to identify if it's an **HP Consumer** or **HP Commercial** model.

    [AGENT SCRIPT - If Commercial Model]:

    "Thank you for that. Since it's a Commercial model, may I ask if this is a company-issued laptop? (If so, please remind the customer that their IT department might have specific procedures for their device.)"

    + HP CONSUMER Notebooks (Pavilion, Envy, Spectre etc)

    *(Agent: Use this section if the laptop is an HP Consumer Model.)*

    + 1. Perform a Hard Reset (Power Drain)

    [Agent Script]:

    Okay, thank you for that information. Let's start with a crucial first step called a 'Hard Reset' or 'Power Drain'. This helps clear any temporary electrical glitches that might be causing the restarts.

    Please follow these steps carefully:
    1. **Shut down your laptop completely.** If it's frozen, press and hold the power button until it turns off.
    2. **Disconnect the AC adapter (charger) from your laptop.**
    3. **Disconnect all external devices** connected to your laptop – this includes any USB drives, external monitors, printers, etc.
    4. Now, **press and hold the power button on your laptop for about 25-30 seconds.** This helps drain any leftover power.
    5. After 25-30 seconds, **reconnect ONLY the AC adapter** to the laptop.
    6. Try to **turn on your laptop**. Please let me know the outcome once this is done.

    + 2. Test the Hard Drive/SSD using HP PC Hardware Diagnostics UEFI

    [Agent Script]:

    If your laptop is still restarting, the next crucial step is to test the hard drive (or SSD) itself. A faulty storage drive can often cause continuous restarts. HP has a built-in diagnostic tool for this.

    Please try this:
    1. **Shut down your laptop.**
    2. **Press the power button**, and immediately start tapping the **F2 key repeatedly** (don't hold it) until you see the HP PC Hardware Diagnostics UEFI screen.
    3. From the menu, choose **'Component Tests'** > **'Storage'** > **'HDD/SSD'**.
    4. Select the **'Quick Test'** option and let it run.
    5. **What was the result of the Quick Test?** Did it Pass or Fail? If it failed, please tell me the 24-digit Failure ID if you see one. I'll wait for your confirmation on the outcome.

    [AGENT HINT for Internal Use]:

    • If Test Fails: A failed HDD/SSD test directly indicates the Storage Drive (HDD/SSD) is faulty. This will require a replacement. Guide customer about hardware failure and check Pre-tool for recommended part number for Storage Drive (HDD/SSD) replacement.
    • If Test Passes: The storage hardware is likely fine. Proceed to the next step.

    + 3. Boot to Safe Mode & Software Troubleshooting

    [Agent Script]:

    If the hard drive test passed, it's possible a corrupt Operating System or a software conflict is causing the restarts. Let's try to boot into Safe Mode, which loads Windows with only essential drivers and services.

    Please try to access the Windows Recovery Environment:
    1. **Shut down your laptop.**
    2. **Press the power button**, and immediately start tapping the **F11 key repeatedly** (don't hold it) until you see the 'Choose an option' screen (it usually has a blue background).
    3. Once on that screen, click on **'Troubleshoot'**.
    4. Select **'Advanced options' > 'Startup Settings' > 'Restart'**.
    5. On the next screen, tap **F5** to select **'Safe Mode with Networking'**.
    6. **If it boots into Safe Mode and is stable (doesn't restart):** This means Windows can load in a basic state. We'll try to disable conflicting programs.
    * In Safe Mode, click the Start button, type `msconfig` in the search bar, and select 'System Configuration'. (Alternatively, press **Windows key + R**, type `msconfig`, and press Enter).
    * Go to the **'Services' tab**. Check 'Hide all Microsoft services'. Click 'Disable all'. Apply, OK, and Restart your laptop normally. If it boots and is stable, a program was causing the issue.
    7. **If it does NOT boot to Safe Mode, or restarts even in Safe Mode:** Please let me know, and we'll move to the next option (System Reset).

    + 4. System Reset & OS Reinstallation

    [Agent Script]: "If Safe Mode didn't help stabilize the laptop, we'll need to consider resetting or reinstalling Windows. We'll start with an option that tries to save your files."

    A. System Reset (Keep My Files):

    This reinstalls Windows, but attempts to keep your personal files. All installed applications will be removed.

    1. From the 'Choose an option' screen (F11 Recovery), select **'Troubleshoot' > 'Reset this PC' > 'Keep my files'**.
    2. Important: While this tries to keep files, it's always safest to have a backup if possible.
    3. Follow the on-screen prompts.
    4. **After it completes:** Please let me know if your laptop boots normally and is stable. If not, we'll proceed to the final option (Full OS Reinstallation).

    B. OS Reinstallation (Remove Everything):

    This is a last resort and will completely erase all data on your hard drive.

    [Agent Script - CRITICAL WARNING]: "Before proceeding, it's *extremely important* to understand that **this step will erase ALL data on your hard drive.** If you have any personal files, photos, or documents that are not backed up, they will be lost. Do you have a recent backup, or is data loss acceptable to proceed?"

    Okay, understood. To proceed with a full OS reinstallation, you have two main methods:

    Method 1 (F11 Recovery - Easiest if it works):
    1. From 'Troubleshoot', select **'Reset this PC' > 'Remove everything'**.
    2. Follow the prompts to proceed.

    Method 2 (USB Recovery Media - If F11 fails or preferred):
    1. On another working PC, please go to **HP's support website** and search for 'HP Cloud Recovery Client'. This tool helps you create a USB drive with the exact factory image for your specific HP model. You'll need your serial number.
    2. Alternatively, you can search for **'Windows Media Creation Tool'** on Microsoft's website. This tool lets you create a bootable USB drive with the latest Windows version.
    3. Once you have the USB drive, plug it into your problematic laptop, then restart and repeatedly tap **F9** (for Boot Device Options). Select the USB drive to boot from it and follow the installation prompts.

    The system will load back to factory settings. Please let me know the outcome once this is complete.

    + 5. Escalation for Hardware Replacement (if applicable)

    [AGENT HINT for Internal Use]:

    • If Step 2 (HDD/SSD Test) FAILED with a Failure ID: The Storage Drive (HDD/SSD) is faulty.
    • If all software steps (Steps 3 & 4) failed and the unit still restarts continuously: It's highly likely a Motherboard issue.
    • ACTION: Before advising replacement, always double-check the identified faulty part (e.g., HDD/SSD, Motherboard) with your Pre-tool to confirm the recommended part for replacement.

    + HP COMMERCIAL Notebooks (EliteBook, ProBook, ZBook etc)

    *(Agent: Use this section if the laptop is an HP Commercial Model.)*

    + 1. Perform a Hard Reset (Power Drain)

    [Agent Script]:

    Okay, thank you for that information. Let's start with a crucial first step called a 'Hard Reset' or 'Power Drain'. This helps clear any temporary electrical glitches that might be causing the restarts.

    Please follow these steps carefully:
    1. **Shut down your laptop completely.** If it's frozen, press and hold the power button until it turns off.
    2. **Disconnect the AC adapter (charger) from your laptop.**
    3. **Disconnect all external devices** connected to your laptop – this includes any USB drives, external monitors, printers, etc.
    4. Now, **press and hold the power button on your laptop for about 25-30 seconds.** This helps drain any leftover power.
    5. After 25-30 seconds, **reconnect ONLY the AC adapter** to the laptop.
    6. Try to **turn on your laptop**. Please let me know the outcome once this is done.

    + 2. Test the Hard Drive/SSD using HP PC Hardware Diagnostics UEFI

    [Agent Script]:

    Please try this:
    1. **Shut down your laptop.**
    2. **Press the power button**, and immediately start tapping the **F2 key repeatedly** (don't hold it) until you see the HP PC Hardware Diagnostics UEFI screen.
    3. From the menu, choose **'Component Tests'** > **'Storage'** > **'HDD/SSD'**.
    4. Select the **'Quick Test'** option and let it run.

    • If Test Passes: The storage hardware is likely fine. Proceed to the next step.

    + 3. Boot to Safe Mode & Software Troubleshooting

    [Agent Script]:

    If the hard drive test passed, it's possible a corrupt Operating System or a software conflict is causing the restarts. Let's try to boot into Safe Mode, which loads Windows with only essential drivers and services.

    Please try to access the Windows Recovery Environment:
    1. **Shut down your laptop.**
    2. **Press the power button**, and immediately start tapping the **F11 key repeatedly** (don't hold it) until you see the 'Choose an option' screen (it usually has a blue background).
    3. Once on that screen, click on **'Troubleshoot'**.
    4. Select **'Advanced options' > 'Startup Settings' > 'Restart'**.
    5. On the next screen, tap **F5** to select **'Safe Mode with Networking'**.
    6. **If it boots into Safe Mode and is stable (doesn't restart):** This means Windows can load in a basic state. We'll try to disable conflicting programs.
    * In Safe Mode, click the Start button, type `msconfig` in the search bar, and select 'System Configuration'. (Alternatively, press **Windows key + R**, type `msconfig`, and press Enter).
    * Go to the **'Services' tab**. Check 'Hide all Microsoft services'. Click 'Disable all'. Apply, OK, and Restart your laptop normally. If it boots and is stable, a program was causing the issue.
    7. **If it does NOT boot to Safe Mode, or restarts even in Safe Mode:** Please let me know, and we'll move to the next option (System Reset).

    + 4. System Reset & OS Reinstallation

    [Agent Script]: "If Safe Mode didn't help stabilize the laptop, we'll need to consider resetting or reinstalling Windows. We'll start with an option that tries to save your files."

    A. System Reset (Keep My Files):

    This reinstalls Windows, but attempts to keep your personal files. All installed applications will be removed.

    1. From the 'Choose an option' screen (F11 Recovery), select **'Troubleshoot' > 'Reset this PC' > 'Keep my files'**.
    2. Important: If this is a company-issued laptop with BitLocker encryption, you will likely need a recovery key from your IT department. Do not proceed without it if prompted.
    3. Follow the on-screen prompts.
    4. **After it completes:** Please let me know if your laptop boots normally and is stable. If not, we'll proceed to the final option (Full OS Reinstallation).

    B. OS Reinstallation (Remove Everything):

    This is a last resort and will completely erase all data on your hard drive.

    [Agent Script - CRITICAL WARNING]: "Before proceeding, it's *extremely important* to understand that **this step will erase ALL data on your hard drive.** If you have any personal files, photos, or documents that are not backed up, they will be lost. Do you have a recent backup, or is data loss acceptable to proceed?"

    [Agent Script - COMPANY LAPTOP WARNING]: "If this is a company-issued laptop, **DO NOT proceed with 'Remove everything'** without first confirming with your IT department. They will have their own secure re-imaging procedures and may need to recover company data."
